title: 112_hr1169
content: The Act titled "National Guard Technician Equity Act" makes amendments to Titles 10 and 32 of the United States Code regarding National Guard Technicians and related provisions. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Titles 10 and 32 of the United States Code to allow non-dual status technicians with 20 years of service to be employed in designated positions. Additionally, an exception to dual-status employment conditions for membership in the Selected Reserve is included. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Titles 10 and 32 of the United States Code to allow non-dual status technicians with 20 years of service to be employed in designated positions. It also includes an exception to dual-status employment conditions for membership in the Selected Reserve. Amendments to sections 10216 and 10217 of title 10 are made regarding compensation and limitations on the number of non-dual status technicians. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 32 of the United States Code by adding a new subsection regarding the rights of grievance, arbitration, appeal, and review for technicians and labor organizations. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 32 of the United States Code to grant technicians and labor organizations rights of grievance, arbitration, appeal, and review beyond the adjutant general to the Merit Systems Protection Board and the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for certain actions. This does not apply to technicians under temporary appointments or in trial periods. The "National Guard Technician Equity Act" amends Title 32 of the United States Code to grant technicians and labor organizations rights of grievance, arbitration, appeal, and review beyond the adjutant general to the Merit Systems Protection Board and the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit for certain actions. This includes amendments to sections 7511 and 7512 of Title 5, United States Code, and eligibility for bonuses and benefits for military technicians under section 10216 of Title 10, United States Code. The National Guard Technician Equity Act allows military technicians to receive enlistment, reenlistment, or affiliation bonuses without repayment obligations. Additionally, technicians can participate in educational loan repayment programs as incentives for maintaining membership in the Selected Reserve. The Act also repeals the prohibition against overtime pay for National Guard technicians. The National Guard Technician Equity Act allows technicians to receive overtime pay at a rate of one and a half times their basic pay or compensatory time off for irregular or overtime work. Amendments to Title 5, United States Code regarding National Guard Technicians and related provisions. Amendment to Title 5, United States Code allows military technicians to receive an annuity upon separation after completing 25 years of service or reaching 50 years of age and completing 20 years of service. Amendment to Title 5, United States Code allows military technicians to receive an annuity upon separation for cause on charges of misconduct or delinquency, or after completing 25 years of service or reaching 50 years of age and completing 20 years of service. Changes include adequate leave time for military activations and improved health care benefits under FEHBP. An employee eligible for benefits under Title 5, United States Code is enrolled in a health benefits plan, a member of a reserve component of the Armed Forces, placed on leave without pay for active duty, and called to various types of active duty or training. Within 6 months of this Act, the Secretary of Defense and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management will study converting military technicians from FEHBP to TRICARE coverage. The Secretary of Defense and the Director of the Office of Personnel Management will study converting military technicians from FEHBP coverage to TRICARE coverage under chapter 55 of title 10, United States Code, during contingency operations. Definitions include FEHBP coverage under chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code, and contingency operation as defined in section 101(a)(13) of title 10, United States Code. SEC. 4. REDUCTION IN ELIGIBILITY AGE FOR RETIREMENT FOR NON-REGULAR SERVICE. Amends Section 12731(f) of title 10, United States Code, by changing the retirement age from 60 to 55 years.
